verses.text: Now a certain man was ill, Lazarus of Bethany, the village of Mary and her sister Martha.
verses.comment: Bethany was a small village near Jerusalem. The focus on Mary and Martha sets the stage for a personal and miraculous event.

verses.text: It was Mary who anointed the Lord with ointment and wiped his feet with her hair, whose brother Lazarus was ill.
verses.comment: This detail anticipates Mary’s later act, showing her devotion and hinting at Jesus’ coming death and burial.

verses.text: So the sisters sent to Him, saying, 'Lord, the one you love is ill.'
verses.comment: The plea does not mention Lazarus’ name, showing their confidence in Jesus’ personal love for him.

verses.text: But when Jesus heard it, He said, 'This illness does not lead to death. It is for the glory of God, so that the Son of God may be glorified through it.'
verses.comment: Jesus connects Lazarus’ sickness with God’s glory and His own divine Sonship, pointing to his unity with the Father.

verses.text: Now Jesus loved Martha and her sister and Lazarus.
verses.comment: John emphasizes Jesus’ love for them, showing his deep human relationships and his divine compassion.

verses.text: So when He heard that Lazarus was ill, He stayed two days longer in the place where He was.
verses.comment: Jesus’ delay is intentional, underscoring the divine timing and purpose of miracles.

verses.text: Then after this He said to the disciples, 'Let us go to Judea again.'
verses.comment: Returning to Judea was dangerous, indicating Jesus’ willingness to face opposition for the sake of his mission.

verses.text: The disciples said to Him, 'Rabbi, the Jews were just now seeking to stone you, and are you going there again?'
verses.comment: The disciples express fear for Jesus’ safety, revealing the real threat he faced, adding gravity to his journey.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'Are there not twelve hours in the day? If anyone walks in the day, he does not stumble, because he sees the light of this world.'
verses.comment: Jesus refers metaphorically to God’s appointed time for his work, affirming His mission is guided by the Father.

verses.text: But if anyone walks in the night, he stumbles, because the light is not in him.
verses.comment: Light here refers to divine guidance. Absence of light implies spiritual blindness or separation from God.

verses.text: After saying these things, He said to them, 'Our friend Lazarus has fallen asleep, but I go to awaken him.'
verses.comment: 'Sleep' is often a biblical metaphor for death, especially when resurrection is in view.

verses.text: The disciples said to Him, 'Lord, if he has fallen asleep, he will recover.'
verses.comment: The disciples misunderstand, thinking Jesus refers to natural sleep, not death.

verses.text: Now Jesus had spoken of his death, but they thought that he meant taking rest in sleep.
verses.comment: Clarifies the confusion between literal and figurative language around life and death.

verses.text: Then Jesus told them plainly, 'Lazarus has died.'
verses.comment: Jesus reveals the reality explicitly, showing knowledge beyond the physical realm.

verses.text: And for your sake I am glad that I was not there, so that you may believe. But let us go to him.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ actions are meant to strengthen faith. The miracle will manifest God's power and invite deeper trust.

verses.text: So Thomas, called the Twin, said to his fellow disciples, 'Let us also go, that we may die with him.'
verses.comment: Thomas shows devotion, even to the point of death. Early Church leaders saw his statement as foreshadowing martyrdom.

verses.text: Now when Jesus came, he found that Lazarus had already been in the tomb four days.
verses.comment: Four days signifies no hope of resuscitation by normal means; the miracle would be unmistakable.

verses.text: Bethany was near Jerusalem, about two miles off,
verses.comment: This closeness explains why many Jews were able to come and comfort the family.

verses.text: and many of the Jews had come to Martha and Mary to console them concerning their brother.
verses.comment: Mourning customs in ancient Israel involved community support for the grieving family.

verses.text: So when Martha heard that Jesus was coming, she went and met him, but Mary remained seated in the house.
verses.comment: Martha’s active faith is in character with what we know of her elsewhere, as contrasted with Mary’s more contemplative waiting.

verses.text: Martha said to Jesus, 'Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died.'
verses.comment: A mixture of faith and disappointment is evident, but there’s also a trust in Jesus’ power.

verses.text: But even now I know that whatever you ask from God, God will give you.'
verses.comment: Martha expresses hope even in sorrow, recognizing Jesus’ special relationship with the Father.

verses.text: Jesus said to her, 'Your brother will rise again.'
verses.comment: References the hope of resurrection found in Jewish tradition (Daniel 12:2). Jesus connects personal faith with future resurrection.

verses.text: Martha said to him, 'I know that he will rise again in the resurrection on the last day.'
verses.comment: Martha’s belief in the final resurrection aligns with mainstream Jewish eschatology. The conversation pivots toward Jesus’ role in that resurrection.

verses.text: Jesus said to her, 'I am the resurrection and the life. Whoever believes in me, though he die, yet shall he live,
verses.comment: The 'I am' statement directly references Yahweh’s self-revelation (Exodus 3:14), making a claim of divinity. Jesus centers resurrection and eternal life in his own person.

verses.text: and everyone who lives and believes in me shall never die. Do you believe this?'
verses.comment: Here Jesus teaches about eternal life that transcends physical death. Belief in Him is the key to unending life.

verses.text: She said to him, 'Yes, Lord; I believe that you are the Christ, the Son of God, who is coming into the world.'
verses.comment: Martha’s profession mirrors Peter’s confession, affirming the Messiah’s divine Sonship—a recurring identity central for the faith and leadership of the Church.

verses.text: When she had said this, she went and called her sister Mary, saying in private, 'The Teacher is here and is calling for you.'
verses.comment: Jesus is referred to as 'Teacher,' emphasizing his role in forming disciples.

verses.text: And when she heard it, she rose quickly and went to him.
verses.comment: Mary responds promptly to Jesus’ call, an example of discipleship both active and receptive.

verses.text: Now Jesus had not yet come into the village, but was still in the place where Martha had met him.
verses.comment: Jesus pauses outside the town, allowing for private approaches from Martha and Mary before the public miracle.

verses.text: When the Jews who were with her in the house, consoling her, saw Mary rise quickly and go out, they followed her, supposing that she was going to the tomb to weep there.
verses.comment: The gathered community witnesses all that is to occur, providing many witnesses to Jesus’ miracle.

verses.text: Now when Mary came to where Jesus was and saw him, she fell at his feet, saying to him, 'Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died.'
verses.comment: Mary’s grief echoes Martha’s earlier words. Both sisters show faith in Jesus’ ability to heal.

verses.text: When Jesus saw her weeping, and the Jews who had come with her also weeping, he was deeply moved in his spirit and greatly troubled.
verses.comment: Jesus’ heartfelt reaction underscores his true humanity and compassion. The Greek here implies a powerful emotional response.

verses.text: And he said, 'Where have you laid him?' They said to him, 'Lord, come and see.'
verses.comment: Jesus participates fully to share their grief, seeking to enter our sorrows as a merciful Lord.

verses.text: Jesus wept.
verses.comment: The shortest verse in the Bible, dramatically showing Jesus' compassion and true humanity. It fulfills prophecy of the Messiah’s identification with his people’s suffering (Isaiah 53:3).

verses.text: So the Jews said, 'See how he loved him!'
verses.comment: Jesus’ actions stir a response from the onlookers, confirming the depth of his love.

verses.text: But some of them said, 'Could not he who opened the eyes of the blind man also have kept this man from dying?'
verses.comment: There is both faith and doubt among the people, referencing Jesus’ earlier miracles and raising questions of God’s will and timing.

verses.text: Then Jesus, deeply moved again, came to the tomb. It was a cave, and a stone lay against it.
verses.comment: Burial in a cave sealed with a stone is a detail that prefigures Jesus’ own burial and resurrection.

verses.text: Jesus said, 'Take away the stone.' Martha, the sister of the dead man, said to him, 'Lord, by this time there will be an odor, for he has been dead four days.'
verses.comment: The physical reality of death is evident; raising Lazarus constitutes a public and undeniable miracle.

verses.text: Jesus said to her, 'Did I not tell you that if you believed you would see the glory of God?'
verses.comment: Faith is required to see God’s glory. Repeated theme: God’s glory revealed through belief and obedience.

verses.text: So they took away the stone. And Jesus lifted up His eyes and said, 'Father, I thank You that You have heard Me.'
verses.comment: Jesus addresses God as Father, reaffirming His unique relationship. His prayer expresses unity of will with the Father, a model for intercessory prayer.

verses.text: I knew that you always hear me, but I said this on account of the people standing around, that they may believe that you sent me.'
verses.comment: The public nature of Jesus’ prayer points to his mission of revealing the Father and calling all to faith. Jesus as the one sent echoes Old Testament language about prophets and the Messiah.

verses.text: When he had said these things, he cried out with a loud voice, 'Lazarus, come out!'
verses.comment: Jesus’ spoken command shows the power of God’s Word. Authority over death is a sign of divine prerogative.

verses.text: The man who had died came out, his hands and feet bound with linen strips, and his face wrapped with a cloth. Jesus said to them, 'Unbind him, and let him go.'
verses.comment: The restoration of Lazarus points to Christ’s power to free us from the bonds of sin and death. The image anticipates the resurrection and the sacraments as means of new life.

verses.text: Many of the Jews therefore, who had come with Mary and had seen what he did, believed in him,
verses.comment: Miracles serve as signs that lead to authentic faith and entry into the one united community of believers.

verses.text: but some of them went to the Pharisees and told them what Jesus had done.
verses.comment: Signs also provoke opposition, revealing division in response to Jesus' works.

verses.text: So the chief priests and the Pharisees gathered the council and said, 'What are we to do? For this man performs many signs.'
verses.comment: The Sanhedrin's reaction shows that Christ's miracles were public knowledge and recognized as supernatural.

verses.text: If we let him go on like this, everyone will believe in him, and the Romans will come and take away both our place and our nation.'
verses.comment: The leaders fear loss of authority and national identity, failing to see the divine plan for a new spiritual people of God.

verses.text: But one of them, Caiaphas, who was high priest that year, said to them, 'You know nothing at all,
verses.comment: Caiaphas, as the high priest, holds a unique place as mediator for the people even when he does not realize he prophesies truly.

verses.text: nor do you understand that it is better for you that one man should die for the people, not that the whole nation should perish.'
verses.comment: Caiaphas unintentionally aligns with prophecy about the suffering servant who dies for the people (Isaiah 53).

verses.text: He did not say this of his own accord, but being high priest that year he prophesied that Jesus would die for the nation,
verses.comment: John reports that even unaware leaders can be instruments of God’s will. Prophecy is not always conscious.

verses.text: and not for the nation only, but also to gather into one the children of God who are scattered abroad.
verses.comment: Jesus’ death unites all God’s people, including Gentiles, into one flock—a foundation for a universal and visible unity among believers.

verses.text: So from that day on they made plans together to put him to death.
verses.comment: The Sanhedrin’s conspiracy marks the beginning of Christ’s Passion, fulfilling prophecies of a rejected and suffering Messiah.

verses.text: Jesus therefore no longer walked openly among the Jews, but went from there to the region near the wilderness, to a town called Ephraim, and there He stayed with the disciples.
verses.comment: Jesus chooses seclusion, indicating both prudence and fulfillment of God’s timetable for his death and resurrection.

verses.text: Now the Passover of the Jews was at hand, and many went up from the country to Jerusalem before the Passover to purify themselves.
verses.comment: Passover foreshadows Jesus’ own sacrificial death, the purification rites point to the need for inward cleansing—fully accomplished in Christ.

verses.text: They were looking for Jesus and saying to one another as they stood in the temple, 'What do you think? That he will not come to the feast at all?'
verses.comment: The crowd’s expectation sets the tension for the drama of Holy Week and the climax of Jesus’ public ministry.

verses.text: Now the chief priests and the Pharisees had given orders that if anyone knew where he was, he should let them know, so that they might arrest him.
verses.comment: The official order for Jesus’ arrest fulfills the prophecy of the suffering and rejected Messiah, further preparing for the events of the Passion.
